nodes.label: Social connection reduces mortality risk by 50%
nodes.summary: Meta-analysis of 148 studies (308,849 participants) shows 50% increased survival likelihood with stronger social relationships. Effect comparable to quitting smoking. Social isolation increases mortality 32%, loneliness 14%. Cross-cultural validity confirmed.

nodes.label: Romantic love found in vast majority of cultures
nodes.summary: Anthropological study by Jankowiak & Fischer (1992) examined 166 cultures, finding romantic love evidence in vast majority. Cross-cultural consistency suggests it's human universal, not Western invention. Includes love songs, elopement, personal anguish.

nodes.label: Wang et al. 2023 meta-analysis
nodes.summary: Meta-analysis published in Nature Human Behaviour analyzing 148 studies with 308,849 participants. Found stronger social relationships increase survival likelihood by 50%, comparable to quitting smoking. Social isolation increases mortality 32%, loneliness 14%.

nodes.label: Jankowiak & Fischer 1992
nodes.summary: Anthropological study published in Ethnology examining 166 cultures, finding evidence of romantic love in vast majority. Used Yale HRAF database. Shows romantic love is human universal, not Western cultural invention.

nodes.label: Meta-analysis of 148 studies with 308,849 participants found 50% increased survival with stronger social relationships
nodes.summary: Meta-analysis by Wang et al. 2023 (Nature Human Behaviour) of 148 studies with 308,849 participants found people with stronger social relationships have 50% increased likelihood of survival. Effect comparable to quitting smoking, exceeds many known risk factors.
